TITLE:
   Chief Complaint:
   HPI:
   24 Hour Events:
   CC: s/p esophageal stent placment admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for respiratory
   distress
   .
   HPI: This is a 74 year old female with recently diagnosed gastric CA,
   s/p resection transfered from [**Hospital3 4838**] for esophageal
   stenting, now admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] after intubation for respiratory stress.
   The follow history is taken from [**Hospital1 **] and [**Hospital1 **] notes. The
   patient underwent EGD in [**2113-9-30**] for w/u anemia. She was found to
   have a gastric mass, poorly differentiated adenocarinoma. On [**11-1**], she
   underwent partial proximal gastrectomy and pylorplasty with J-tube
   placment. She was discharged home on [**11-9**] but returned to the ED later
   that day for hematemasis. EGD was done showing some clots in the
   stomach but no active bleeding. The follwing day she had another
   episode of hematemasis, was transfered to the ICU and electively
   intubated for airway protection.  She underwent repeat endoscopy which
   showed a small separtion in one portion of the esophagastric anatomosis
   with oozing. She then underwent exlap on [**11-11**] where a tear in the
   capusle of the spleen was found, but was not able to be repaired given
   concerns with disrupting the anastomosis. [**Female First Name (un) **] was controlled with
   thombin-soaked Gel foam, bleeding stopped. She then underwent an
   arteriogram showing a 6mm splnic pseuoaneurysm. She was transfussed
   multipe unitls during these few days, HCT around 26. She was on Zosyn
   and fluconazol 200mg IV daily.
   .
   She was transfered to [**Hospital1 **] SICU for treatment on the pseudoaneurysm.
   She was taken to IR for stenting of of splenic artery aneursym. She was
   weaned off the ventilator. However, she was noted to be on 3L NC duirng
   ambulance transport. Lasix was given. There was a question of vomiting
   enroute. She was then reintubated on [**11-18**] for respiratory distress and
   hypotension on [**11-18**]. She was diuresed for the following two days and
   then extubated on [**11-20**]. On [**11-20**], she underwent CT chest, which only
   showed moderate pleural effusions. On [**11-22**], she was switched from
   Zosyn to Cefepime.
   .
   During this time a CT abdomen, demonstrated perforation of the GE
   junction by the NG tube. NGT was pulled back and secured.Gastrografin
   swallow  on [**2113-11-23**] showed a contained anastomotic leak to the left of
   the remaining stomach measuring approx 6x3cm. She was then transfered
   to [**Hospital1 1**] for esophagastric stenting.
   .
   Here she underwent ERCP with placement of esophagastric metal 9cm x10mm
   stent proximal clipping. She stent placement was verified by a
   pediatric scope. She had been electively intubated prior to the
   procedure and was extubated post ERCP. Post proceedure, she was
   ordered125ml/hr NS; she likely received 400cc LR during the procedure.
   She then developed respiratory distress with respiratory rates in 40's,
   no documented hypoxia.  She was then reintubated in the PACU. She was
   given lasix 20mg IV in the PACU. She was transfered to the floor on AC
   500x 14, FI02 50%, PEEP 5.
   .
   ROS: unable to obtain
   .
   PMH:
   gastric CA s/p resection
   breast ca s/p mastectomy
   partial thyroidectomy for thyroid CA
   bladder CA s/p transurethral resection
   HTN
   Splenic artery aneurysm s/p stenting
   .
   Home Medications:
   Arimidex 1mg daily
   Diovan 80mg daily
   ASA 81mg daily
   Prilosec 20mg da day
   Carafate 1 gram per day
   Calcium
   Vit D
   Toprol Xl 50mg daily
   .
   Medications on Transfer:
   Albuterol
   Ipratropium
   Cefepime 1gram q12
   Fluconazole 200mg IV once a day
   Heparin 5000 units TID
   hydromorphine 0.6mg -1,g q2-4hrs PRN pain
   Reglan 5mg IV q 6hrs
   lopressor 75mg [**Hospital1 **]
   Zofran 5mg IV q 6hrs
   Percocet 5mg
   protonix 40mg q12hrs
   Insulin sliding scale
   Diovan 80mg qhs via j-tube
   ASA 81mg via J-tube
   .
   Allergies: Percocet, Tape
   .
   Social History: Married and lives with her husband, children live
   nearby, she is a former smoker of less than one pack per day, she
   drinks wine occaisonally
   .
   Family History: breast ca, sister with gastric CA, a sister with lung
   CA, CAD and COPD in various family members
   .
   Physical Exam:
   Vitals: T:99.4 P: 88 BP:138/61 R: 14 SaO2: 98& F102 50%
   General: intubated sedasted
   HEENT: MMM, no lesions noted in OP, no JVD
   Pulmonary: Lungs CTA bilaterally
   Cardiac: RRR, nl. S1S2, no M/R/G noted
   Abdomen: soft, NT/ND, hypoactive bowel sounds, midline healing incision
   with slight erythema but no edema or drainag, JP inplace with minimal
   serous fluid, J-tube in place with some yellow discharge but no edema
   Extremities: No C/C/E bilaterally, 2+ radial, DP and PT pulses b/l.
   Skin: no rashes or lesions noted.
   Neurologic:
   -mental status: intubated sedate, occ opens eyes, moving her head and
   coughing but not moving extremities
   .
   Laboratory Data: see below
   .
   EKG [**Hospital1 **] [**11-6**]: sinus tachy at 106, left axis, deep TWI in
   V2-V3,  TWF in V4-V6, I, AVL, ? q waves in III, AVF, no ST elevations
   or depressions
   EKG [**Hospital1 1**]: TWI in V2-V6
   .
   Radiologic Data:
   - CXR [**Hospital1 1**]: pulmonary edema, small left sided efffusion
   - CXR [**11-24**] from [**Hospital1 **]: mild edema, left pleural effusion
   -CT abd w/ contrast [**11-20**]:
   1. extraluminal gas collection to the lefto the body of the somach, NG
   tubes through an area of surgical clips in the GE junction into this
   extraluminal gas collection, findings compatible with perforation at
   the GE junction
   2. retroperitoneal hematoma in the right anterio pararenal space
   3. J-tube in place
   - Bilateral LENI's [**11-20**]: no DVT avobe the knees
   - Gastrografin swallow [**2113-11-23**]:  contained anastomotic leak to the
   left of the remaining stomack measuring approx 6x3cm
   -  CT Chest [**11-20**]: no PE, bilateral moderal pleural effusion L>R
   Allergies:
   Adhesive Tape (Topical)
   itching;
   Percocet (Oral) (Oxycodone Hcl/Acetaminophen)
   itching;
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Cefipime - [**2113-11-24**] 09:15 PM
   Infusions:

   Other ICU medications:
   Fentanyl - [**2113-11-24**] 11:30 PM

   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 74 year old female with recently diagnosed gastric CA, s/p
   resection transfered from [**Hospital3 4838**] for esophageal stenting,
   now admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] after intubation for respiratory stress.
   .
   # Respiratory distress: Characterized as tachypnea. This is the fourth
   time she has been intubated - 1) hematemasis 2) respiratory distress 3)
   for ERCP 4)respiratory distress. Per the family, she had significant
   anxiety on one extubation to the extent that she needed to be
   reintubated immediately [**2-13**] distress; she was anxious that her husband
   was not present. This level of anxiety may have resulted in
   reintubation today. However, there is also evidence of volume overload
   on CXR and given the rapidity with which she went into distress, she
   may have had flash pulmonary edema. No PNA, no sputum production, fever
   or leukocytosis. No hypoxia on ABG. Of note, she was sat'ing 98% on 3L
   NC prior to ERCP.
   - intubated, propofol and fentanyl
   - diurese with lasix 10mg IV, f/u UOP
   - nebs
   - [**Month (only) 202**] Fi02
   - RSBI and SBT in am
   - may need ativan peri-extubation and family at bedside
   - consider peri-extubation CPAP and nitro drip
   - echo for ? diastolic dsyfunction
   .
   # Anastamotic leak: s/p stenting
   - cefepime day 2, fluconazole
   .
   # S/p gastrectomy:
   - J-tube and tube feeds
   - fentanyl boluses for pain while intubated, but will transition back
   to percocet and dilauded
   .
   # TWI on EKG: same as prior
   - will not r/o
   .
   # HTN
   - cont metoprolol and diovan
   .
   #) Prophylaxis: PPI, sc heparin
   .
   #) FEN: TF, NPO
   .
   #) Access: PIVs, TLC, a-line
   .
   #) Code Status: Full
   .
   #) Dispo: pending further work-up and treatment
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Arterial Line - [**2113-11-24**] 07:29 PM
   Multi Lumen - [**2113-11-24**] 07:30 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Boots, SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer: PPI
   VAP: HOB elevation, Mouth care, Daily wake up, RSBI
   Need for restraints reviewed
   Comments:
   Communication: Family meeting held , ICU consent signed Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition: ICU

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old female with a history of gastric cancer, s/p resection, and esophageal stenting. She was admitted to the ICU after intubation for respiratory distress. The patient has a complex medical history, including breast cancer, partial thyroidectomy, and bladder cancer. She has been experiencing respiratory distress, which has led to multiple intubations. The patient's current condition is characterized by tachypnea, no documented hypoxia, and evidence of volume overload on CXR.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Anastomotic leak: The patient has a contained anastomotic leak to the left of the remaining stomach, which may lead to further complications, such as infection, abscess formation, or perforation.
2. Respiratory distress: The patient's repeated episodes of respiratory distress may lead to further complications, such as pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), or respiratory failure.
3. Volume overload: The patient's evidence of volume overload on CXR may lead to further complications, such as cardiac failure, pulmonary edema, or respiratory failure.
4. Sepsis: The patient's history of bleeding, surgery, and intubation may increase the risk of sepsis, which could lead to further complications, such as organ failure or death.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of gastric cancer and gastrectomy may increase the risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding, obstruction, or perforation.
6. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of hypertension and thyroid cancer may increase the risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, heart failure, or myocardial infarction.
7. Neurological complications: The patient's history of breast cancer and partial thyroidectomy may increase the risk of neurological complications, such as seizures, stroke, or cognitive impairment.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's current condition is characterized by respiratory distress, anastomotic leak, and volume overload. The plan is to intubate the patient and provide mechanical ventilation, diurese with lasix, and nebs. The patient will also receive antibiotics for prophylaxis against infection. The plan is to consider peri-extubation CPAP and nitro drip, as well as echo for diastolic dysfunction. The patient's code status is full code, and her disposition is pending further work-up and treatment.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old female who was recently diagnosed with gastric cancer and underwent resection. She was transferred to the ICU for respiratory distress and intubation. The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.7°C (99.9°F)
* Heart rate: 93 bpm (normal range)
* Blood pressure: 81/48 mmHg (normal range)
* Respiratory rate: 21 inspirations per minute (normal range)
* Oxygen saturation: 99%

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* Intubated and sedated, but arousable to voice commands
* Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally
* Cardiac examination reveals regular rhythm, normal S1 and S2 sounds, and no murmurs
* Abdomen is soft, with a midline incision site showing slight erythema but no edema or drainage
* Extremities show no cyanosis, edema, or clubbing
* Skin shows no rashes or lesions

Laboratory results include:

* White blood cell count: 12.6 K/uL (normal range)
* Hemoglobin: 9.1 g/dL (normal range)
* Platelet count: 465 K/uL (normal range)
* Creatinine: 1.0 mg/dL (normal range)
* Blood glucose: 84 mg/dL (normal range)

The patient's current medical conditions include:

* Gastric cancer with recent resection
* Anastamotic leak
* S/p gastrectomy
* HTN
* Prophylaxis for DVT and stress ulcer
* VAP prophylaxis

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory distress due to pneumonia, fluid overload, or anxiety
* Anastamotic leak or fistula
* Sepsis or infection
* Diastolic dysfunction or heart failure
* Hypertensive crisis
* VAP or ventilator-associated pneumonia
* Gastrointestinal bleeding or obstruction

The plan for the patient's care includes:

* Weaning propofol and fentanyl sedation
* Weaning sedation and FiO2
* Administering additional IV Lasix for diuresis
* Following fever curve and WBC counts
* Considering peri-extubation ativan and nitro drip
* Evaluating diastolic dysfunction with echo and TTE
* Continuing to follow up on laboratory results and imaging studies.

TITLE:
   Chief Complaint:
   HPI:
   24 Hour Events:
   CC: s/p esophageal stent placment admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for respiratory
   distress
   .
   HPI: This is a 74 year old female with recently diagnosed gastric CA,
   s/p resection transfered from [**Hospital3 4838**] for esophageal
   stenting, now admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] after intubation for respiratory stress.
   The follow history is taken from [**Hospital1 **] and [**Hospital1 **] notes. The
   patient underwent EGD in [**2113-9-30**] for w/u anemia. She was found to
   have a gastric mass, poorly differentiated adenocarinoma. On [**11-1**], she
   underwent partial proximal gastrectomy and pylorplasty with J-tube
   placment. She was discharged home on [**11-9**] but returned to the ED later
   that day for hematemasis. EGD was done showing some clots in the
   stomach but no active bleeding. The follwing day she had another
   episode of hematemasis, was transfered to the ICU and electively
   intubated for airway protection.  She underwent repeat endoscopy which
   showed a small separtion in one portion of the esophagastric anatomosis
   with oozing. She then underwent exlap on [**11-11**] where a tear in the
   capusle of the spleen was found, but was not able to be repaired given
   concerns with disrupting the anastomosis. [**Female First Name (un) **] was controlled with
   thombin-soaked Gel foam, bleeding stopped. She then underwent an
   arteriogram showing a 6mm splnic pseuoaneurysm. She was transfussed
   multipe unitls during these few days, HCT around 26. She was on Zosyn
   and fluconazol 200mg IV daily.
   .
   She was transfered to [**Hospital1 **] SICU for treatment on the pseudoaneurysm.
   She was taken to IR for stenting of of splenic artery aneursym. She was
   weaned off the ventilator. However, she was noted to be on 3L NC duirng
   ambulance transport. Lasix was given. There was a question of vomiting
   enroute. She was then reintubated on [**11-18**] for respiratory distress and
   hypotension on [**11-18**]. She was diuresed for the following two days and
   then extubated on [**11-20**]. On [**11-20**], she underwent CT chest, which only
   showed moderate pleural effusions. On [**11-22**], she was switched from
   Zosyn to Cefepime.
   .
   During this time a CT abdomen, demonstrated perforation of the GE
   junction by the NG tube. NGT was pulled back and secured.Gastrografin
   swallow  on [**2113-11-23**] showed a contained anastomotic leak to the left of
   the remaining stomach measuring approx 6x3cm. She was then transfered
   to [**Hospital1 1**] for esophagastric stenting.
   .
   Here she underwent ERCP with placement of esophagastric metal 9cm x10mm
   stent proximal clipping. She stent placement was verified by a
   pediatric scope. She had been electively intubated prior to the
   procedure and was extubated post ERCP. Post proceedure, she was
   ordered125ml/hr NS; she likely received 400cc LR during the procedure.
   She then developed respiratory distress with respiratory rates in 40's,
   no documented hypoxia.  She was then reintubated in the PACU. She was
   given lasix 20mg IV in the PACU. She was transfered to the floor on AC
   500x 14, FI02 50%, PEEP 5.
   .
   ROS: unable to obtain
   .
   PMH:
   gastric CA s/p resection
   breast ca s/p mastectomy
   partial thyroidectomy for thyroid CA
   bladder CA s/p transurethral resection
   HTN
   Splenic artery aneurysm s/p stenting
   .

   Prilosec 20mg da day
   Carafate 1 gram per day

   .

   Cefepime 1gram q12

   Heparin 5000 units TID
   hydromorphine 0.6mg -1,g q2-4hrs PRN pain
   Reglan 5mg IV q 6hrs
   lopressor 75mg [**Hospital1 **]
   Zofran 5mg IV q 6hrs
   Percocet 5mg
   protonix 40mg q12hrs
   Insulin sliding scale
   Diovan 80mg qhs via j-tube
   ASA 81mg via J-tube
   .
   Allergies: Percocet, Tape
   .
   Social History: Married and lives with her husband, children live
   nearby, she is a former smoker of less than one pack per day, she
   drinks wine occaisonally
   .
   Family History: breast ca, sister with gastric CA, a sister with lung
   CA, CAD and COPD in various family members
   .

   Extremities: No C/C/E bilaterally, 2+ radial, DP and PT pulses b/l.
   Skin: no rashes or lesions noted.
   Neurologic:
   -mental status: intubated sedate, occ opens eyes, moving her head and
   coughing but not moving extremities
   .
   Laboratory Data: see below
   .
   EKG [**Hospital1 **] [**11-6**]: sinus tachy at 106, left axis, deep TWI in
   V2-V3,  TWF in V4-V6, I, AVL, ? q waves in III, AVF, no ST elevations

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old female who underwent gastric cancer resection and esophageal stenting. She was admitted to the ICU for respiratory distress, which has been a recurring issue since her initial admission. The patient has a history of gastric cancer, breast cancer, partial thyroidectomy, and bladder cancer. She is currently intubated and sedated, with a respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute and an SpO2 of 99%.

The patient has undergone several procedures, including ERCP with esophagogastric metal stent placement, which was complicated by a contained anastomotic leak. She has also had multiple episodes of hematemesis, which has been managed with endoscopy and thrombin-soaked gel foam.

The patient's current condition is characterized by respiratory distress, which is thought to be related to volume overload and possibly flash pulmonary edema. She is being treated with diuretics, nebs, and FiO2. The patient's anastomotic leak is being managed with antibiotics and antifungal medication.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress could progress to respiratory failure, which would require invasive mechanical ventilation and potentially lead to further complications such as pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome.
2. Anastomotic leak: The patient's contained anastomotic leak could worsen and lead to peritonitis, abscess formation, or sepsis.
3. Sepsis: The patient's multiple episodes of hematemesis and anastomotic leak increase her risk of developing sepsis, which could lead to organ failure and death.
4. Pneumonia: The patient's intubation and respiratory distress increase her risk of developing pneumonia, which could be complicated by the patient's underlying medical conditions.
5. Diastolic dysfunction: The patient's TWI on EKG could be indicative of diastolic dysfunction, which could lead to heart failure and further complications.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of hematemesis and anastomotic leak increase her risk of developing gastrointestinal bleeding, which could be life-threatening.
7. Wound infection: The patient's midline healing incision could become infected, leading to further complications and prolonged hospitalization.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust therapy as necessary to prevent respiratory failure.
2. Continue to manage the patient's anastomotic leak with antibiotics and antifungal medication, and consider further interventions such as stent placement or surgical revision.
3. Monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely for signs of sepsis or organ dysfunction.
4. Consider early mobilization and physical therapy to prevent respiratory and gastrointestinal complications.
5. Continue to manage the patient's pain and discomfort with medication and other interventions, and consider referral to pain management specialists if necessary.
6. Consider referral to gastroenterology and cardiology specialists for further management of the patient's anastomotic leak and diastolic dysfunction.
7. Continue to educate the patient and her family about her condition, treatment options, and potential complications to ensure informed decision-making.

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old woman with a complicated GI history who was admitted for stent placement in the connection between her esophagus and stomach. She developed acute respiratory distress post-extubation following the procedure and was reintubated in the PACU. The patient is currently sedated and intubated, with a respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute and a SpO2 of 100%. She has a history of anemia, and her vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 81 beats per minute, blood pressure of 81/48 mmHg, and a temperature of 37.7°C. The patient has a Foley catheter in place and is receiving IV fluids and antibiotics.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory rate is high, and she is receiving mechanical ventilation. She may be at risk for respiratory failure due to her underlying lung disease and the need for prolonged mechanical ventilation.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a history of anemia, which may be a sign of underlying sepsis. She is receiving antibiotics, but further evaluation is needed to rule out sepsis.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's ECG shows T-wave inversions laterally, which may be a sign of cardiac ischemia. She is receiving beta blockers and diuretics, but further monitoring is needed to rule out cardiac complications.
4. Volume overload: The patient has a history of volume overload, which may be contributing to her respiratory distress. She is receiving diuretics, but further evaluation is needed to rule out volume overload.
5. Aspiration: The patient has a history of aspiration, which may be contributing to her respiratory distress. She is receiving bronchodilators, but further evaluation is needed to rule out aspiration.
6. Infection: The patient has a history of infection, which may be contributing to her respiratory distress. She is receiving antibiotics, but further evaluation is needed to rule out infection.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust her mechanical ventilation settings as needed.
2. Continue to evaluate the patient for sepsis and cardiac complications, and adjust her treatment plan accordingly.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's volume status and adjust her diuretic therapy as needed.
4. Consider adding bronchodilators to the patient's treatment plan to help manage her respiratory distress.
5. Consider adding IV TNG to the patient's treatment plan to help manage her respiratory distress.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust her treatment plan accordingly.
7. Consider adding stress ulcer prophylaxis to the patient's treatment plan to help manage her risk of stress ulcers.

The patient, a 74-year-old female, is a post-gastrectomy patient with a recently diagnosed gastric cancer who was transferred to the ICU for respiratory stress. She was intubated and is currently receiving mechanical ventilation. Her condition is stable, with no significant changes in her vital signs, laboratory results, or imaging studies. She is at risk for pulmonary edema post-extubation and will require close monitoring.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pulmonary Edema: The patient is at risk for developing pulmonary edema post-extubation, which can be life-threatening. Close monitoring of her respiratory status and fluid balance is essential.
2. Anastamotic Leak: The patient has a history of anastamotic leak, which can lead to sepsis and other complications. Continuous antibiotics and antifungal therapy are necessary to prevent infection.
3. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient has a J-tube and tube feeds, which can lead to gastrointestinal complications such as nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Close monitoring of her gastrointestinal status is essential.
4. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient has a history of hypertension and is receiving medications to control her blood pressure. Close monitoring of her cardiovascular status is essential to prevent cardiovascular complications.
5. Infection: The patient is at risk for developing infections due to her prolonged hospitalization and immunosuppressed state. Close monitoring of her laboratory results and imaging studies is essential to detect any signs of infection early.
6. Sepsis: The patient is at risk for developing sepsis due to her anastamotic leak and immunosuppressed state. Close monitoring of her vital signs and laboratory results is essential to detect any signs of sepsis early.
7. Respiratory Failure: The patient is at risk for developing respiratory failure due to her underlying lung disease and prolonged mechanical ventilation. Close monitoring of her respiratory status is essential to prevent respiratory failure.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of gastric cancer, who underwent resection and esophageal stenting, and is currently admitted to the ICU for respiratory distress.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.7°C (99.9°F)
* Heart rate: 78 bpm (normal range: 73-93 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 132/66 mmHg (normal range: 132/66 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 21 breaths per minute (normal range: 19-34 breaths per minute)
* Oxygen saturation: 95%
* Heart rhythm: Sinus rhythm

The patient's physical examination is notable for:

* Intubated and sedated, but arousable to voice commands
* No lesions or rashes noted on the skin
* Soft, non-tender abdomen with hypoactive bowel sounds
* Midline healing incision with slight erythema but no edema or drainage

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 12.6-12.9 K/uL (normal range: 4.5-11.5 K/uL)
* Hemoglobin: 9.4 g/dL (normal range: 12.1-16.3 g/dL)
* Platelet count: 465-464 K/uL (normal range: 150-450 K/uL)
* Creatinine: 1.0-1.1 mg/dL (normal range: 0.5-1.2 mg/dL)
* Troponin-T: 0.02 ng/mL (normal range: 0-0.1 ng/mL)
* Calcium: 8.0 mg/dL (normal range: 8.5-10.5 mg/dL)
* Magnesium: 2.1 mg/dL (normal range: 1.8-2.5 mg/dL)
* Phosphate: 3.5 mg/dL (normal range: 2.5-4.5 mg/dL)

The patient's radiology results show:

* Chest X-ray: bilateral lung infiltrates
* Electrocardiogram: resolution of transient ST-segment elevation in V5-V6

The patient's medical complications and potential medical complications include:

* Respiratory distress: failure to extubate secondary to anxiety, flash edema/fluid overload, or pneumonia/infectious process
* Anastamotic leak: s/p stenting
* S/p gastrectomy: J-tube and tube feeds
* TWI on EKG: unchanged from prior EKG
* HTN: cont metoprolol and diovan
* Prophylaxis: PPI, sc heparin

The patient's plan includes:

* Weaning propofol and fentanyl
* Weaning sedation and FiO2
* Another 10mg of IV Lasix, f/u UOP
* F/u PM Lytes
* F/u CXR after diuresis
* Nebulization
* Consider peri-extubation nitro drip
* Echo to evaluate for diastolic dysfunction
* Continue to follow fever curve, WBC counts
* Cefepime and fluconazole for anastamotic leak
* J-tube and tube feeds for s/p gastrectomy
* Repeat EKG for TWI
* Continue metoprolol and diovan for HTN
* PPI and sc heparin for prophylaxis

The patient's ICU care includes:

* Nutrition: tube feeds/NPO
* Glycemic control
* Lines: arterial line, multi-lumen
* Prophylaxis: DVT, stress ulcer, VAP
* Need for restraints reviewed
* Code status: full code
* Disposition: ICU pending further work-up and treatment.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual who was admitted with acute respiratory failure post-extubation in the PACU. The patient's condition has been stabilized, and they are currently being managed in the ICU.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.7°C, heart rate of 77 bpm, and blood pressure of 132/66 mmHg. The patient's respiratory status is also stable, with a SpO2 of 94% on 40% FiO2. The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation with a CPAP/PSV mode, with a PEEP of 5 cmH2O and a FiO2 of 40%.

The patient's laboratory results show that they have a white blood cell count of 12.6, hemoglobin of 9.4 g/dL, and platelet count of 465 K/uL. The patient's electrolytes are also within normal limits, with a sodium of 138 mmol/L, potassium of 4.6 mmol/L, and chloride of 28 mmol/L.

The patient's medical history is significant for hypertension, which has been poorly controlled in the past, leading to flash pulmonary edema. The patient is currently receiving treatment with metoprolol and valsartin, and their blood pressure is being closely monitored.

The patient's physical examination is significant for crackles in the dependent lung fields, indicating a possible pulmonary edema. The patient's abdomen is soft and non-tender, and their extremities are without edema.

The patient's neurologic examination is significant for attentive behavior, with the ability to follow simple commands and respond to verbal stimuli. The patient's tone is not assessed due to their respiratory distress.

The patient's diagnosis is acute respiratory failure, which is likely secondary to their poorly controlled hypertension. The patient's plan is to receive lasix and IV TNG to decrease preload, and to anticipate extubation in the morning.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

* Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and they are at risk for developing pneumonia.
* Sepsis: The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, indicating an inflammatory response, which can lead to sepsis.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's hypertension and flash pulmonary edema put them at risk for cardiac complications, such as myocardial infarction or cardiac arrest.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and they are at risk for developing respiratory failure.
* Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state and respiratory distress make them susceptible to infection.
* Bleeding: The patient's platelet count is low, which can increase their risk of bleeding.

Overall, the patient's condition is critical, and they require close monitoring and management to prevent complications and improve their outcome.

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old female who was recently diagnosed with gastric cancer, underwent resection, and was transferred to the ICU for respiratory stress. She was successfully extubated yesterday and is currently being monitored for potential complications. Her vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.4°C, heart rate of 88 bpm, and blood pressure of 134/59 mmHg. Her respiratory support includes nasal cannula oxygen and positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 0 cmH2O. Her laboratory results show mild anemia, elevated white blood cell count, and normal kidney function.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pulmonary Edema: The patient is at risk for developing pulmonary edema post-extubation, which may be exacerbated by her recent gastric surgery and potential anastomotic leak.
2. Anastomotic Leak: The patient has a history of anastomotic leak and is at risk for further complications, including sepsis and peritonitis.
3. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's recent gastric surgery and potential anastomotic leak increase her risk for gastrointestinal bleeding, which may be life-threatening.
4. Wound Infection: The patient's midline healing incision is at risk for infection, which may be complicated by her recent surgery and potential anastomotic leak.
5. Respiratory Failure: The patient's recent respiratory failure and potential anastomotic leak increase her risk for further respiratory complications, including pneumonia and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
6. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's recent surgery and potential anastomotic leak increase her risk for cardiovascular complications, including arrhythmias and heart failure.
7. Infection: The patient's recent surgery and potential anastomotic leak increase her risk for infection, which may be life-threatening.
8. Nutritional Complications: The patient's recent surgery and potential anastomotic leak increase her risk for nutritional complications, including malnutrition and dehydration.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's current plan includes ongoing monitoring for potential complications, including pulmonary edema, anastomotic leak, and gastrointestinal bleeding. She will also require ongoing nutritional support and close monitoring of her laboratory results. Further surgical consultation and management will be necessary to address her anastomotic leak and potential gastrointestinal bleeding.

Summary:

The patient, a 74-year-old female, was successfully extubated yesterday and is currently being managed in the ICU. She is complaining of nausea, but her pain is under control. Her respiratory status is stable, with a SpO2 of 98% on 3L NC. Her vital signs are within normal limits, with a temperature of 37.4°C, heart rate of 88 bpm, and blood pressure of 134/59 mmHg. She has a central venous catheter, arterial line, and urinary catheter in place.

The patient has a recent history of gastric cancer, and underwent resection and esophageal stenting. She was intubated for respiratory stress and is now being managed in the ICU. She has a J-tube in place for tube feeds and a JP drain in place for management of anastamotic leak.

Potential medical complications:

1. Anastamotic leak: The patient's recent history of gastric cancer and esophageal stenting increases the risk of anastamotic leak. Close monitoring of the patient's abdominal status and further evaluation with imaging studies may be necessary to identify any complications.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's recent history of respiratory stress and intubation increases the risk of respiratory failure. Close monitoring of the patient's respiratory status and further evaluation with imaging studies may be necessary to identify any complications.
3. Infection: The patient's recent history of gastric cancer and esophageal stenting increases the risk of infection. Close monitoring of the patient's vital signs and further evaluation with imaging studies may be necessary to identify any complications.
4. Bleeding: The patient's recent history of gastric cancer and esophageal stenting increases the risk of bleeding. Close monitoring of the patient's vital signs and further evaluation with imaging studies may be necessary to identify any complications.
5. Diastolic dysfunction: The patient's recent history of gastric cancer and esophageal stenting increases the risk of diastolic dysfunction. Further evaluation with echocardiography may be necessary to identify any complications.
6. Hypertension: The patient's recent history of gastric cancer and esophageal stenting increases the risk of hypertension. Close monitoring of the patient's blood pressure and further evaluation with imaging studies may be necessary to identify any complications.
7. Hyperglycemia: The patient's recent history of gastric cancer and esophageal stenting increases the risk of hyperglycemia. Close monitoring of the patient's blood glucose levels and further evaluation with imaging studies may be necessary to identify any complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old female with recently diagnosed gastric cancer, who underwent resection and was transferred to the ICU for esophageal stenting. The patient was intubated for respiratory stress and is now extubated.

The patient is currently receiving various medications, including lasix, zofran, and compazine for nausea, as well as furosemide, labetalol, pantoprazole, and morphine sulfate for other conditions. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.4°C, heart rate of 88 bpm, and blood pressure of 134/59 mmHg.

The patient's respiratory status is improving, with a respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute and an SpO2 of 98%. The patient is receiving oxygen therapy via nasal cannula and is being monitored for pulmonary edema.

The patient's abdominal wound is healing well, with minimal serosanguinous fluid drainage and no signs of infection.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 12.1, hemoglobin of 28.9, and platelet count of 479. The patient's creatinine level is 1.0 mg/dL, and the patient's troponin-T level is 0.02 ng/mL.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is at risk for pulmonary edema post-extubation and will need to be monitored closely.
2. Anastamotic leak: The patient will continue to receive cefepime and fluconazole, and a surgery consult will be obtained.
3. S/p gastrectomy: The patient will continue to receive tube feeds and J-tube, and will transition back to percocet and dilauded for pain management.
4. TWI on EKG: The patient's TWI in V5, V6 has resolved, and enzymes are flat.
5. HTN: The patient will continue to receive metoprolol and diovan.

5. Infection: The patient is at risk for infection due to the surgical site and may require further management.

Overall, the patient's condition is stable, and they will require close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old female who was recently diagnosed with gastric cancer and underwent resection. She was transferred to the ICU after intubation for respiratory stress and was extubated today. She is currently receiving various medications, including lasix, zofran, and compazine, and has a nasogastric tube and tube feeds. Her vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.4°C, heart rate of 88 bpm, and blood pressure of 134/59 mmHg. Her respiratory support includes oxygen delivery through a nasal cannula and a PSV/SBT ventilator mode. She has a history of anastomotic leak and is being treated with cefepime and fluconazole. She also has a history of hypertension and is being treated with metoprolol and diovan.

Potential medical complications:

1. Pulmonary edema: The patient's recent intubation and respiratory stress may increase her risk of developing pulmonary edema, which could worsen her respiratory status.
2. Anastomotic leak: The patient's history of anastomotic leak and ongoing treatment with cefepime and fluconazole may increase her risk of developing further complications, such as infection or bleeding.
3. Hypertension: The patient's history of hypertension and ongoing treatment with metoprolol and diovan may increase her risk of developing further complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or kidney damage.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of gastric cancer and ongoing treatment with tube feeds may increase her risk of developing gastrointestinal bleeding.
5. Infection: The patient's history of recent surgery and ongoing treatment with antibiotics may increase her risk of developing infection.
6. Respiratory failure: The patient's recent intubation and respiratory stress may increase her risk of developing respiratory failure, which could worsen her overall condition.
7. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of hypertension and ongoing treatment with metoprolol and diovan may increase her risk of developing cardiac arrhythmias.
8. Kidney damage: The patient's history of hypertension and ongoing treatment with lasix may increase her risk of developing kidney damage.
9. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's history of tube feeds may increase her risk of developing nutritional deficiencies, such as malnutrition or electrolyte imbalances.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.1°C, heart rate of 82 bpm, blood pressure of 153/79 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 96%. Their respiratory support includes nasal cannula oxygen and intermittent positive pressure ventilation.

The patient's laboratory results show normal white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet count, with slightly elevated creatinine and potassium levels. Their troponin-T level is normal, and their electrocardiogram shows a normal sinus rhythm.

1. Pneumonia: Given the patient's respiratory failure and history of anastomotic leak, there is a risk of developing pneumonia.
2. Anastomotic Leak: The patient's anastomotic leak is ongoing, and there is a risk of further complications, such as bleeding or infection.

4. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is ongoing, and there is a risk of further complications, such as respiratory arrest or need for mechanical ventilation.
5. Infection: The patient's history of anastomotic leak and respiratory failure increases their risk of developing an infection.
6. Bleeding: The patient's anastomotic leak increases their risk of bleeding, which could lead to further complications.
7. Cardiac Complications: The patient's hypertension and history of cardiac surgery increase their risk of developing cardiac complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or heart failure.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following medical complications can arise:

1. Cardiac Arrest: The patient has a history of cardiac arrest, and there is an unclear etiology. The patient is at risk for torsades de pointes due to electrolyte abnormalities and proarrhythmic medications.
2. Hypotension: The patient is experiencing hypotension, which may be due to infectious etiology, blood loss, or cardiac failure. The patient's hemoglobin is dropping, and abdominal exam shows increased distension and tenderness.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to acute respiratory failure. The patient has a reduced ejection fraction and may be at risk for volume overload.
4. Bleeding: The patient is actively bleeding, likely into the abdomen, and may require surgery.
5. Infection: The patient is at risk for infection due to the cardiac arrest, hypotension, and respiratory failure.
6. Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient has hypokalemia and hypophosphatemia, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias and other complications.
7. Gastrointestinal Issues: The patient has a distended abdomen and is at risk for gastrointestinal bleeding and perforation.
8. Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine is elevated, and the patient may be at risk for acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
9. Coagulopathy: The patient's platelet count is low, and the patient may be at risk for bleeding complications.
10. Nutritional Deficiencies: The patient's nutritional status is compromised, and the patient may be at risk for malnutrition and related complications.

Based on the patient's condition, it is essential to monitor the patient closely and manage the patient's care aggressively to prevent complications and improve outcomes.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of gastric cancer, who has undergone resection and esophageal stenting. She was initially admitted to the ICU for respiratory distress due to pulmonary edema, which resolved. She was later readmitted to the ICU after a pulseless VT/VF arrest.

The patient's current condition is critical, with ongoing bleeding from a splenic hematoma, requiring multiple units of blood transfusions. She has also been diagnosed with probable CAD, CHF, and anastomotic leak.

The potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

1. Continued bleeding from the splenic hematoma, which can lead to further blood loss and organ failure.
2. Development of cardiac arrhythmias or ischemic events due to CAD, which can be exacerbated by the patient's ongoing bleeding and cardiac dysfunction.
3. Progression of CHF, leading to further fluid overload and respiratory failure.
4. Anastomotic leak, which can lead to peritonitis, sepsis, and organ failure.
5. Development of DVT or PE due to immobility and prolonged hospitalization.
6. Respiratory failure due to ongoing bleeding, cardiac dysfunction, or anastomotic leak.
7. Sepsis or septic shock due to ongoing bleeding, anastomotic leak, or other underlying infections.

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

1. Ongoing blood transfusions to correct anemia and bleeding.
2. Cardiac monitoring and management to prevent cardiac arrhythmias and ischemic events.
3. Fluid management to prevent fluid overload and CHF.
4. Anastomotic leak management, including tube feeds and antibiotics.
5. DVT prophylaxis with heparin subcutaneous injections.
6. Respiratory support, including mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy.
7. Pain management with analgesics and anxiolytics.

The patient's disposition is currently ICU care, with plans for transfer to the floor when stable. However, due to her ongoing critical condition, she will require close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

   74 year old female with recently diagnosed gastric CA, s/p resection
   transferred from [**Hospital3 4838**] for esophageal stenting, initially
   admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for respiratory failure [**2-13**] pulmonary edema, then
   extubated and called out to medical floor.  Readmitted to MICU s/p
   pulseless VT/VF arrest, then diagnosed with splenic laceration
   requiring massive transfusion and splenic artery embolization.
   .
   # Splenic artery laceration: s/p embolization by IR with recently
   stable Hcts. Patient had known old splenic laceration, but reason for
   re-bleed is unclear.  It is possible that the bleeding was exacerbated
   by CPR, but the patient had abdominal pain prior to her arrest,
   suggesting that the bleed could have begun before the arrest.
   -- f/u IR and surgery recommendations
   -- Check Hct Q4H
   -- Monitor vitals closely
   -- Transfuse for any drop in Hct
   -- Maintain active T+S with multiple units crossed
   .
   # s/p cardiac arrest -- now with return to sinus rhythm. No known
   cardiac history but echo with LV systolic dysfunction c/w CAD, so there
   is concern for an ischemic event as an etiology.
   -- Repeat EKG this a.m.
   -- Repeat echo
   -- Cycle enzymes
   -- f/u cardiology recs
   -- holding ASA in the setting of recent massive bleeding
   -- holding metoprolol in the setting of recent massive bleeding
   -- maintain K>4, Mg>2
   .
   # Pericardial effusion: Found on CT chest. Patient is s/p CPR.
   -- echocardiogram to further characterize and evaluate hemodynamic
   significance.
   .
   # Mechanical ventilation/Airway protection: Pt has now been intubated 5
   times (1) hematemasis 2) respiratory distress 3) for ERCP 4)respiratory
   distress following extubation 5) code blue/cardiac arrest with feeble
   respirations. Currently the patient is at high risk of aspiration given
   secretions in esophagus and requires airway protection.
   -- Most recent ABG shows good oxygenation and ventilation. Continue
   current vent settings
   .
   # Probable CAD
   [**Hospital **] medical management with statin.
   -- Hold ASA, BB, and [**Last Name (un) 284**] as above
   -- f/u cards c/s
   -- cycle enyzmes as above
   -- serial EKGs
   -- repeat echo as above
   .
   # CHF: No role for diuresis in setting of recent massive bleeding.
   .
   # Tachycardia: DDx includes hypovolemia ([**2-13**] hemorrhage), pain, sepsis.
   -- pull central venous line placed at outside hospital
   -- treat pain adequately
   -- low threshold for blood transfusion
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Likely [**2-13**] hypoperfusion in the setting of
   cardiac arrest and hemorrhage from splenic lac.
   -- monitor urine output and BP
   -- maintain renal perfusion
   .
   # Anastamotic leak: s/p stenting. Prior to the patient
s recent
   bleeding, the plan was for the patient to remain NPO, with feeds via
   J-tube. Currently patient has massively distended abdomen and fluid in
   esophagus.
   -- d/c antibiotics
   -- hold TFs given massive abdominal distending and fluid in esophagus
   .
   # S/p gastrectomy:
   -- holding tube feeds
   -- Pain meds prn
   -- f/u surgery recs
   .
   # Benign HTN:
   -- holding metoprolol and diovan

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU after suffering a pulseless VT/VF arrest, followed by a diagnosis of splenic laceration requiring massive transfusion and splenic artery embolization. The patient has a history of gastric cancer, and the reason for the re-bleed is unclear.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T 36.7°C, HR 109 bpm, BP 109/62 mmHg, RR 18 breaths/min, SpO2 96%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient is receiving multiple units of blood and platelets, and her HCT has stabilized at 33%.
* Fluid balance: The patient has received 6,260 mL of IV fluids and has a total fluid output of 567 mL.
* Respiratory support: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 50%.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient has a history of cardiac arrest, and her ECG shows sinus rhythm. She is receiving medications to manage her cardiac condition.
* Abdominal status: The patient has a tense and distended abdomen with a midline incision and a JP drain in place. She has a J-tube in place for nutrition.
* Extremities: The patient has clean dressings in place over her right femoral artery puncture site and left femoral central venous line.
* Laboratory results: The patient's laboratory results show anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated lactate levels.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Continued bleeding from the splenic laceration
* Development of acute kidney injury due to hypovolemia and cardiac arrest
* Respiratory failure due to inadequate oxygenation and ventilation
* Cardiac complications such as arrhythmias, ischemia, and infarction
* Sepsis due to infection and hypoperfusion
* Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to fluid overload and lung injury
* Gastrointestinal complications such as anastomotic leak and abdominal distension
* Neurological complications such as stroke and seizures due to hypoperfusion and cardiac arrest

The patient's care plan includes:

* Monitoring of vital signs, laboratory results, and fluid balance
* Administration of medications to manage cardiac and respiratory status
* Maintenance of adequate nutrition and hydration
* Monitoring of abdominal and extremity status
* Prevention of complications such as DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP
* Communication with the family and patient regarding the patient's condition and treatment plan.

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU after experiencing a pulseless VT/VF arrest. She had recently undergone gastric cancer resection and was transferred to the ICU for respiratory failure and pulmonary edema. The patient was diagnosed with a splenic laceration requiring massive transfusion and splenic artery embolization. She has a history of cardiac arrest, and an echocardiogram revealed LV systolic dysfunction consistent with CAD. The patient is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory distress and risk of aspiration.

Medical Complications:

1. Splenic laceration: The patient has a splenic laceration that requires ongoing transfusion and monitoring. The reason for the re-bleed is unclear, but it may be related to CPR or pre-existing abdominal pain.
2. Cardiac arrest: The patient had a pulseless VT/VF arrest, and an echocardiogram revealed LV systolic dysfunction consistent with CAD. This may be an ischemic event.
3. Pericardial effusion: A CT chest revealed a pericardial effusion, which requires further evaluation and management.
4. Mechanical ventilation/Airway protection: The patient is at high risk of aspiration due to secretions in the esophagus and requires airway protection.
5. Probable CAD: The patient has a history of CAD, and medical management with a statin is recommended.
6. CHF: The patient has a history of CHF, but diuresis is not indicated in the setting of recent massive bleeding.
7. Tachycardia: The patient has a tachycardia that may be due to hypovolemia, pain, or sepsis.
8. Anastamotic leak: The patient has an anastamotic leak s/p stenting, which requires further management.
9. S/p gastrectomy: The patient has a history of gastrectomy, and tube feeds are being held.
10. Benign HTN: The patient has a history of benign HTN, and medications such as metoprolol and diovan are being held.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs closely and transfuse as needed.
2. Repeat EKG and echo to further evaluate cardiac function.
3. Cycle enzymes to monitor for cardiac damage.
4. F/u cardiology recommendations.
5. Hold ASA, BB, and other medications as previously mentioned.
6. Monitor for signs of bleeding and transfuse as needed.
7. Continue mechanical ventilation and airway protection.
8. F/u surgery recommendations.
9. Replete electrolytes aggressively to maintain K>4.0 and Mg>2.0.
10. Consider placing peripherals and removing the femoral line.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual with a chief complaint of hypotension and intra-abdominal hemorrhage. The patient has undergone multiple interventions, including embolization of the splenic artery, blood product transfusions, and aggressive volume resuscitation.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient's blood pressure is 125/71 mmHg, and their heart rate is 121 bpm.
* Respiratory support: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 450 mL and a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has a sinus tachycardia and is receiving fentanyl and midazolam infusions.
* Abdominal: The patient has a distended and tender abdomen with diffuse tenderness on palpation.
* Neurological: The patient is sedated and unable to provide a history.

The patient has the following potential medical complications:

* Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is slightly increased, and they are anuric overnight. They are making urine this morning following aggressive volume resuscitation.
* Cardiac arrest: The patient has had a cardiac arrest triggered by acute hemorrhage, and cardiac enzymes have been flat.
* Respiratory failure: The patient remains intubated and sedated in the setting of abdominal bleed and is at risk for volume overload.
* Leukocytosis: The patient has leukocytosis, which may be stress-related in the setting of acute events.
* Hypertension: The patient has hypertension, which is being managed with antihypertensive medications.

The patient's current medications include:

* Fentanyl infusion
* Midazolam infusion
* Furosemide (Lasix)
* Cefipime antibiotics
* Antihypertensive medications

The patient's plan includes:

* Monitoring for cardiac arrest and respiratory failure
* Continuation of respiratory support with mechanical ventilation
* Monitoring for signs of infection and adjusting antibiotic therapy as needed
* Monitoring for signs of hypertension and adjusting antihypertensive therapy as needed.

   Acid:1.8 mmol/L, Albumin:2.4 g/dL, LDH:304 IU/L, Ca++:8.0 mg/dL,
   Mg++:3.0 mg/dL, PO4:3.7 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   74 year old female with recently diagnosed gastric CA, s/p resection,
   transferred from [**Hospital3 4838**] for esophageal stenting, initially
   admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for respiratory failure [**2-13**] pulmonary edema, then
   extubated and called out to medical floor.  Readmitted to MICU s/p
   pulseless VT/VF arrest, then diagnosed with splenic laceration
   requiring massive transfusion and splenic artery embolization.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Pt has now been intubated 5 times (1)
   hematemasis 2) respiratory distress 3) for ERCP 4)respiratory distress
   following extubation 5) code blue/cardiac arrest with feeble
   respirations. Currently, the patient appears to be volume-overloaded
   and would likely not tolerate extubation without further diruesis.
   -- Diurese with goal net negative 1L today
   -- Continue mechanical ventilation
   .
   # Splenic artery laceration s/p embolization by IR: Hct generally
   stable although slowly trending down.
   -- f/u IR and surgery recommendations
   -- Check Hct Q6H
   -- Transfuse for Hct<30
   -- Maintain active T+S with multiple units crossed
   -- Consider repeat tagged RBC scan if Hct continues to trend down
   .
   # s/p cardiac arrest/probable CAD -- No known cardiac history but echo
   with LV systolic dysfunction c/w CAD, so there is concern for an
   ischemic event as an etiology.
   -- Monitor on telemetry: frequent ectopy but no other events
   -- Cardiac enzymes unchanged
   -- f/u cardiology recs
   -- holding ASA, [**Last Name (un) 284**] in the setting of recent massive bleeding
   -- restart metoprolol
   -- continue atorvastatin
   -- maintain K>4, Mg>2
   .
   # Pericardial effusion: Found on CT chest. Patient is s/p CPR.
   -- Echocardiogram shows fat pad but not effusion
   .
   # CHF: Volume overload
   -- Diurese slowly with goal net negative 1 L today
   .
   # Leukocytosis: WBC up to 22.2.  Could be reaction to acute stress of
   bleed, but also concerning for infection. Have already pulled femoral
   line placed during code.
   -- pan culture
   -- check differential
 shows 88 neutrophils and 5 bands
   -- continue antibiotics (cefepime and fluconazole), consider adding
   gram positive coverage pending culture results
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Differential diagnosis includes ATN,
   obstruction, intraabdominal compartment syndrome.
   -- monitor urine output
   -- maintain renal perfusion
   -- check bladder pressure
   -- renal U/S
   .
   # s/p gastrectomy complicated by anastamotic leak s/p stenting:
   Followed by surgery and GI
   -- restart tube feeding via J-tube
   -- f/u GI and surgery recs
   -- pain meds PRN
   .
   # HTN:
   -- restart metoprolol
   -- holding Diovan in setting of ARF and recent bleeding
   .
   # h/o breast CA
   -- continue Arimidex
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: restart tube feeds, replete lytes aggressively to maintain
   K>4.0, Mg>2.0
   Glycemic Control: insulin SC
   Lines:
   Interval jugular CVL
   Will attempt to place peripherals
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: pneumoboots
   Stress ulcer: pantoprazole
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments: family
   Code status: DNR
   Disposition: ICU

Summary:

The patient is a 74-year-old female admitted to the ICU after a recent diagnosis of gastric cancer, resection, and subsequent complications. She has been intubated five times due to respiratory failure, hematemesis, and cardiac arrest. She has a splenic artery laceration requiring embolization, and her hemoglobin levels are trending down. She has also experienced cardiac arrest, probable CAD, and is at risk for an ischemic event. She has a pericardial effusion, CHF, leukocytosis, acute renal failure, and anastamotic leak following gastrectomy.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and she is at risk for further respiratory distress or failure.
2. Splenic artery laceration: The patient's hemoglobin levels are trending down, and she may require further transfusions to maintain a stable hemoglobin level.
3. Cardiac arrest: The patient's cardiac status is concerning, and she is at risk for further cardiac events, including ischemic events.
4. Pericardial effusion: The patient's pericardial effusion is a concern, and she may require further evaluation and management.
5. CHF: The patient's CHF is a concern, and she may require further diuresis and management to alleviate volume overload.
6. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis may be a reaction to acute stress or a sign of infection, and further evaluation and management are necessary.
7. Acute renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure is a concern, and further evaluation and management are necessary to determine the cause and potential treatment options.
8. Anastamotic leak: The patient's anastamotic leak following gastrectomy is a concern, and further evaluation and management are necessary to ensure proper healing and prevent further complications.
9. HTN: The patient's HTN is a concern, and further evaluation and management are necessary to determine the cause and potential treatment options.
10. Breast CA: The patient's history of breast CA is a concern, and further evaluation and management are necessary to ensure proper treatment and monitoring.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old female who has been admitted to the ICU multiple times for various complications related to her gastric cancer diagnosis, including respiratory failure, pulmonary edema, and cardiac arrest. The patient has a history of old splenic laceration, which was recently exacerbated by a pulseless VT/VF arrest and required massive transfusion and splenic artery embolization.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: Tachycardic (102 bpm), hypotensive (129/68 mmHg), and hypoxemic (97% SpO2)
* Respiratory status: Intubated and mechanically ventilated with a respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute
* Hemodynamic monitoring: Central venous line and arterial line in place
* Fluid balance: Total input of 5,534 mL, total output of 499 mL, with a balance of 5,035 mL
* Laboratory results: Hemoglobin (Hb) 10.8 g/dL, hematocrit (Hct) 34%, platelet count (Plt) 224,000/μL, white blood cell count (WBC) 17.6, and creatinine (Cr) 1.4 mg/dL

The patient has several potential medical complications, including:

1. Splenic artery laceration: The patient has a history of old splenic laceration, which was recently exacerbated by a pulseless VT/VF arrest and required massive transfusion and splenic artery embolization. The patient's Hct is currently 34%, which is within the normal range.
2. Cardiac arrest: The patient has a history of cardiac arrest, which was treated with CPR and defibrillation. The patient's EKG shows sinus rhythm, and the patient is being monitored for signs of cardiac instability.
3. Pericardial effusion: The patient has a pericardial effusion, which was detected on CT chest. The patient's EKG shows sinus rhythm, and the patient is being monitored for signs of cardiac instability.
4. Mechanical ventilation/Airway protection: The patient is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated, which is necessary to protect the patient's airway due to the risk of aspiration.
5. Probable CAD: The patient has a history of cardiac disease, and the patient's EKG shows signs of cardiac disease. The patient is being monitored for signs of cardiac instability.
6. CHF: The patient has a history of cardiac disease, and the patient's EKG shows signs of cardiac disease. The patient is being monitored for signs of cardiac instability.
7. Tachycardia: The patient's heart rate is currently 102 bpm, which is above the normal range. The patient's tachycardia may be due to hypovolemia, pain, or sepsis.
8. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is currently 1.4 mg/dL, which is above the normal range. The patient's acute renal failure may be due to hypoperfusion in the setting of cardiac arrest and hemorrhage from splenic lac.
9. Anastamotic leak: The patient has a history of gastrectomy and stenting, and the patient's current condition may be related to an anastamotic leak.
10. S/p gastrectomy: The patient has a history of gastrectomy and is currently receiving nutrition via J-tube.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential medical complications, the following plan is recommended:

* Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and hemodynamic status closely.
* Maintain active T+S with multiple units crossed.
* Transfuse for any drop in Hct.
* Maintain K>4.0, Mg>2.0, and Ca++>8.0 mg/dL.
* Hold ASA, BB, and [Last Name (un) 284] as above.
* F/u cards c/s.
* Cycle enyzmes as above.
* Serial EKGs.
* Repeat echo as above.
* Monitor urine output and BP.
* Maintain renal perfusion.
* D/c antibiotics.
* Hold TFs given massive abdominal distending and fluid in esophagus.
* F/u surgery recs.
* Hold metoprolol and diovan.
* Continue to replete lytes aggressively to maintain K>4.0, Mg>2.0.
* Continue to monitor the patient's airway and respiratory status closely.
* Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status closely.
* Continue to monitor the patient's renal status closely.
* Continue to monitor the patient's liver function closely.
* Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels closely.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure and pulmonary edema. She had a recent diagnosis of gastric cancer and underwent resection. She was transferred to the ICU from another hospital for esophageal stenting. 

The patient suffered a pulseless VT/VF arrest and was diagnosed with a splenic laceration requiring massive transfusion and splenic artery embolization. She had a known old splenic laceration, but the reason for re-bleed is unclear. 

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient's blood pressure is 129/68 mmHg, with a heart rate of 102 bpm. She is receiving midazolam and fentanyl infusions for sedation and pain management.
* Respiratory support: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 450 mL and a respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute.
* Laboratory results: The patient's hemoglobin level is 10.8 g/dL, platelet count is 184 K/uL, and white blood cell count is 17.6 K/uL. Her creatinine level is 1.4 mg/dL, and her troponin-T level is 0.03 ng/mL.
* Physical examination: The patient is intubated and sedated, with a tense and distended abdomen. She has a midline incision and a JP drain in place.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Sepsis: The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, and she has a history of recent surgery and bleeding.
* Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and she has a history of cardiac arrest and hemorrhage.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's troponin-T level is elevated, and she has a history of cardiac arrest and LV systolic dysfunction.
* Pulmonary complications: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation, and she has a history of pulmonary edema.
* Abdominal complications: The patient has a tense and distended abdomen, and she has a history of recent surgery and bleeding.
* Hemorrhagic complications: The patient has a history of massive bleeding from a splenic laceration, and she may be at risk for further bleeding.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Monitoring her hemodynamic status closely and transfusing blood products as needed.
* Maintaining active warming with multiple units crossed.
* Repeat EKG and echo studies to further evaluate her cardiac status.
* Serial ABG studies to monitor her respiratory status.
* Monitoring her urine output and blood pressure to assess her renal function.
* Maintaining a low threshold for blood transfusion.
* Holding antibiotics and tube feeds due to the patient's abdominal distension and fluid in the esophagus.
* F/u with cardiology and surgery regarding the patient's cardiac and abdominal status.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual with respiratory failure and splenic hemorrhage. The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode, with a FiO2 of 50% and a PEEP of 5 cmH2O. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6°C, heart rate of 102 bpm, and blood pressure of 127/67 mmHg. The patient's laboratory results show anemia, hypovolemia, and acute renal failure, as well as elevated liver enzymes and troponin levels.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if the mechanical ventilation is not optimized, or if there is a delay in weaning from the ventilator.
2. Splenic Hemorrhage: The patient's splenic hemorrhage may continue to bleed, leading to further blood loss and potential organ dysfunction.
3. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if further blood loss occurs, or if there is a delay in transfusing additional blood products.
4. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure may progress to chronic kidney disease if not managed appropriately.
5. Congestive Heart Failure: The patient's congestive heart failure may worsen if not managed with diuretics and other medications.
6. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis may indicate an underlying infection, which could lead to sepsis and organ dysfunction if not treated promptly.
7. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia may lead to neurological complications if not managed with free water replacement.
8. Infection: The patient is at risk for infection due to the splenic hemorrhage and the presence of foreign bodies, such as the endotracheal tube and arterial line.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely to detect any changes or complications early.

5. Monitor the patient's leukocytosis and consider sending blood and urine cultures to rule out infection.

7. Consider antibiotics and antifungal therapy to prevent and treat infection, and consider abdominal CT scan if the patient develops signs of infection.
8. Monitor the patient's cardiovascular status and consider medications such as beta blockers to manage hypertension and tachycardia.

   Assessment and Plan
   74 year old female with recently diagnosed gastric CA, s/p resection,
   transferred from [**Hospital3 4838**] for esophageal stenting, initially
   admitted to [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for respiratory failure [**2-13**] pulmonary edema, then
   extubated and called out to medical floor.  Readmitted to MICU s/p
   pulseless VT/VF arrest, then diagnosed with splenic laceration
   requiring massive transfusion and splenic artery embolization.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Pt has now been intubated 5 times (1)
   hematemasis 2) respiratory distress 3) for ERCP 4)respiratory distress
   following extubation 5) code blue/cardiac arrest with feeble
   respirations. Currently, the patient appears to be volume-overloaded
   and would likely not tolerate extubation without further diruesis.
   -- Diurese with goal net negative 1L today
   -- Continue mechanical ventilation
   .
   # Splenic artery laceration s/p embolization by IR: Hct generally
   stable although slowly trending down.
   -- f/u IR and surgery recommendations
   -- Check Hct Q6H
   -- Transfuse for Hct<30
   -- Maintain active T+S with multiple units crossed
   -- Consider repeat tagged RBC scan if Hct continues to trend down
   .
   # s/p cardiac arrest/probable CAD -- No known cardiac history but echo
   with LV systolic dysfunction c/w CAD, so there is concern for an
   ischemic event as an etiology.
   -- Monitor on telemetry: frequent ectopy but no other events
   -- Cardiac enzymes unchanged
   -- f/u cardiology recs
   -- holding ASA, [**Last Name (un) 284**] in the setting of recent massive bleeding
   -- restart metoprolol
   -- continue atorvastatin
   -- maintain K>4, Mg>2
   .
   # Pericardial effusion: Found on CT chest. Patient is s/p CPR.
   -- Echocardiogram shows fat pad but not effusion
   .
   # CHF: Volume overload
   -- Diurese slowly with goal net negative 1 L today
   .
   # Leukocytosis: WBC up to 22.2.  Could be reaction to acute stress of
   bleed, but also concerning for infection. Have already pulled femoral
   line placed during code.
   -- pan culture
   -- check differential
 shows 88 neutrophils and 5 bands
   -- continue antibiotics (cefepime and fluconazole), consider adding
   gram positive coverage pending culture results
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Differential diagnosis includes ATN,
   obstruction, intraabdominal compartment syndrome.
   -- monitor urine output
   -- maintain renal perfusion
   -- check bladder pressure
   -- renal U/S
   .
   # s/p gastrectomy complicated by anastamotic leak s/p stenting:
   Followed by surgery and GI
   -- restart tube feeding via J-tube
   -- f/u GI and surgery recs
   -- pain meds PRN
   .
   # HTN:
   -- restart metoprolol
   -- holding Diovan in setting of ARF and recent bleeding
   .
   # h/o breast CA
   -- continue Arimidex
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: restart tube feeds, replete lytes aggressively to maintain
   K>4.0, Mg>2.0
   Glycemic Control: insulin SC
   Lines:
   Interval jugular CVL
   Will attempt to place peripherals
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: pneumoboots
   Stress ulcer: pantoprazole
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments: family
   Code status: DNR
   Disposition: ICU

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old female with a complex medical history, including gastric cancer, recent splenic laceration, and cardiac arrest. She is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. The patient is also experiencing volume overload, acute renal failure, and leukocytosis.

The potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's continued need for mechanical ventilation and potential for respiratory distress or failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's leukocytosis and potential for infection, particularly in the setting of a recent splenic laceration and cardiac arrest.
3. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's acute renal failure and potential for further deterioration in kidney function.
4. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's history of cardiac arrest and potential for further cardiac complications, including arrhythmias or myocardial infarction.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of gastrectomy and anastomotic leak, with potential for further complications such as bleeding, perforation, or obstruction.
6. Hemodynamic instability: The patient's ongoing bleeding and potential for further hemorrhage, as well as her history of cardiac arrest and potential for further cardiac complications.
7. Infection: The patient's potential for infection, particularly in the setting of a recent splenic laceration and cardiac arrest.
8. Fluid overload: The patient's ongoing fluid overload and potential for further fluid accumulation, which could exacerbate her respiratory and cardiovascular instability.

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

1. Mechanical ventilation: To support the patient's respiratory function and prevent further respiratory distress.
2. Diuresis: To manage the patient's volume overload and prevent further fluid accumulation.
3. Antibiotics: To prevent and treat potential infections, particularly in the setting of a recent splenic laceration and cardiac arrest.
4. Cardiovascular medications: To manage the patient's cardiovascular instability and prevent further cardiac complications.
5. Pain management: To manage the patient's pain and discomfort, particularly in the setting of her recent surgical procedures.
6. Nutrition: To provide the patient with adequate nutrition and hydration, particularly in the setting of her ongoing bleeding and potential for further fluid loss.

The patient's code status is DNR, and her disposition is ICU.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old female with a complex medical history, including gastric cancer, recent cardiac arrest, and splenic laceration requiring embolization. She is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.8°C, heart rate of 114 bpm, and blood pressure of 138/67 mmHg. Her respiratory rate is 28 breaths per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 97%.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 9.6 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 22.2 x 10^9/L
* Platelet count: 184 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.3 mg/dL
* Potassium: 3.6 mmol/L
* Magnesium: 2.7 mg/dL
* Calcium: 8.4 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 4.2 mg/dL

The patient's physical examination shows:

* Intubated and sedated
* Decreased breath sounds at bases bilaterally
* Tense and distended abdomen
* Markedly tender to palpation
* 1+ bilateral lower extremity edema

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Gastric cancer
* Cardiac arrest with probable CAD
* Splenic laceration with embolization
* Pericardial effusion
* Chronic heart failure
* Leukocytosis
* Acute renal failure
* Anastomotic leak after gastrectomy
* Hypertension

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac arrest
* Splenic rupture
* Pericardial tamponade
* Renal failure
* Intraabdominal compartment syndrome
* Anastomotic leak
* Hypertensive crisis

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Diuresis with goal net negative 2L today
* Check electrolytes tid and replete for K>4, Mg>2
* Continue mechanical ventilation
* Monitor on telemetry for frequent ectopy
* F/u cardiology recommendations
* Hold ASA and atorvastatin in the setting of recent massive bleeding
* Continue metoprolol and atorvastatin
* Maintain K>4, Mg>2
* Diurese slowly with goal net negative 2L today
* F/u blood and urine cultures
* Continue antibiotics and consider adding gram-positive coverage pending culture results
* Send urine eos and monitor urine output
* Maintain renal perfusion
* Check bladder pressures
* Add IV Reglan for vomiting
* Hold tube feeding for now
* F/u GI and surgery recommendations
* Pain meds PRN
* Continue Arimidex
* ICU care, including nutrition, glycemic control, and prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.
